bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, December 11, 1947

div1.p: Hench requests Cooke's help in identifying photographs taken at Pinar del Rio. Hench is interested because Haskins, a prisoner at Pinar del Rio, died of yellow fever, but his cell-mates escaped the disease. This impressed Reed with the possibilities of the mosquito theory.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, December 11, 1947
div1.opener:
December 11, 1947
Dr. Robert P. Cooke
Lexington - Rockbridge Health Department
Lexington, Virginia
My dear Doctor Cooke:
div1.p:
It has been a long time since we have corresponded. About a week
ago I gave my illustrated lecture on the “Conquest of Yellow Fever” at the
University of Virginia Medical School, on invitation of Alpha Omega Alpha
Medical Fraternity. As I always do in that lecture, I included a slide with
your photograph and I called attention to the fact that actually four Univer-
sity of Virginia men were among those concerned with my story: Major Reed,
General Kean, Johnny Moran (who later went to the University) and yourself.

I now write to you again for some information and I am most hope-
ful that you can help me out because you are probably the only one alive who
can.

You of course remember the epidemic of yellow fever at Pinar del Rio
in the spring of 1900. You remember that first Agramonte, then Reed and a
few days later Lazear, went from Havana to Pinar del Rio to investigate the
epidemic. A post mortem was made on a soldier, Arthur Haskins (or Harkins)
who had been a prisoner in a cell at Pinar del Rio, had gotten yellow fever
and died just about the time Agramonte arrived at Pinar. His cell-mates (who
had slept in the same cell, eaten the same food, etc.) escaped the disease and
this fact impressed Reed with the possibilities of the mosquito theory. This
story has often been mentioned by Reed and others. Therefore the case of
Prisoner Arthur Harkins has a certain historical importance.

In reconstructing the entire story for my book I had hoped to find
old photographs of the barracks, perhaps the prison cell, etc. On my trips
to Cuba I have not yet had time to go to Pinar to see whether or not the
buildings still remain. In my examinations of old Army records, maps, etc.,
I did not run across anything thereon until recently.

Several years ago (about 1941) while rambling through some old Army
photographic files in Washington, I did find six photographs of Pinar del Rio,
copies of which I enclose, identified as follows: (see numbers on the photos)
1. (113459; MID - 225) (SC-113459) - Cuban Pacification about 1908
Spanish Cuartel, interior view of quadrangle, Pinar del Rio, Cuba,
M.I.D.
2. (113460; MID - 223) (SC 113460) - “Cuban Pacification about 1908,
Spanish Cuartel, front View, Pinar del Rio, Cuba.”
3. (113461) (SC 113461) Cuban Pacification about 1908. Pinar del
Rio, Cuba.
Dr. Robert P. Cooke
- 2 -
December 11, 1947
4. (113463; MID - 219) (SC 113463) - "Cuban Pacification about
1908, general view of the south west from roof of Cuartel: 1 - House
used by regimental commissary and quartermaster. 2 - City reservoir.
3 - Regimental and Q. M. stables. 4 and 6 - Wooden barrack buildings,
built for United States Troups in intervention now occupied by rural
guards. 5 - Cascade Salud Hospital, Pinar del Rio, Cuba, January 1989.
(These numbers are not marked on my copy of this photo.)
5. (R B 4094) Pinar del Rio Barracks.
6. (No file number) Hospital camp, Pinar del Rio, Cuba, 1898.

Although most of these photos were taken in 1908, I assumed that these
same buildings were used by the American troups in 1898 - 1900, but couldn't be
absolutely sure. I also wondered whether the prison in which Arther Haskins was
kept was shown in any of these views but of this also I could not be sure.

A few months ago General Truby (you surely have read his fine book on
the yellow fever episode) made me the repository of data he used for his book.
I have been slowly studying and digesting this material and recently found in
General Truby's copy of “Annual Report of Brigadier General Fitzhugh Lee, A.G.O.
Quemados, Cuba, August 23, 1900” the following statement in report 5, pages six and
seven (statement signed by Major J. R. Kean, dated August 20, 1900). "Acting
Assistant Surgeon Agramonte was then sent to inspect, and arrived on the 19th,
in time to hold an autopsy in the case of general prisoner Arthur Harkins (God-
frey's report named him Haskins) who died on the 18th. The typical lesions of
yellow fever were found. He reported three well marked cases in hospital,
seven suspects and 2 convalescents.

"The command was put into camp on the 22nd instant, there having been
meanwhile three more deaths making a total of 12.....

“The origin of the fever is now difficult to determine. The infantry
battalion with their band were quartered in the Cuartel, a fine old Spanish
barrack, which has been most carefully renovated and disinfected prior to its
occupation by American troops. The guard house was also in this building. Just
off the reservation and not more than 100 yards from the Cuartel is a collection
of squalid eating houses, saloons, etc. The rest of the command were quartered
in new barracks constructed a year ago.... The fact that 65 per cent of the cases
come from the Cuartel and that among them were three general prisoners would in-
dicate that the Cuartel was infected.”

When I recently found these statements I came to the belief that the
photographs Nos. 1 and 2 (Spanish Cuartel) which I had gotten about 1941 were
in all probability photographs of the very same Cuartel used in your day by the
American troups and that in this same Cuartel was the guard house and prison
in which Prisoner Haskins had taken ill.

Now, Doctor Cooke, I am most anxious for you to examine these old
photographs and see if you can help identify the buildings therein. Can you
specifically answer these questions?

list.item:
1. Is the Spanish Cuartel (photos 1 and 2) the same one used in
1900 by the American troops with which you served?

2. Please note photo 2: Where was the prison (guard house) in
this view? Note that all the windows on the first floor are
barred which leads me to believe that not only the prison windows
were barred but others also on the first floor.

3. Note in photo 2 the horse-drawn ambulance outside the entrance
just to the right of the central passage-way. Was the hospital
also in this Cuartel or was the ambulance at the Cuartel perhaps
to remove someone from the Cuartel to the hospital situated elsewhere?

4. See photo 1. Does the interior photo show the prison? What
were the small ground shacks at right angles to the main building
used for?

5. Photo 3 was obviously taken from the roof of the Cuartel. Can
you help me identify the various buildings in this photo? Am I
correct in assuming that the two long one-story buildings in the
left background were “the new barracks constructed a year ago” (in
1899)? What is the 2 story building in the center background? Is
your hospital shown in this photo?

6. Please see photo 4 and its title. Can you place for me the sub-
numbers mentioned in the title (but not marked in on the face of my
photo)? It mentions the Casade Salud Hospital (1909). Was this your
hospital? If not, does your hospital show in this photo? If so,
please mark in ink on the photo and return to me.
7. Please see photo RB 4094 (photo 5). Can you identify it further?

8. Please se photo 6, labelled “Hospital camp, Pinar del Rio 1898”.
Can you identify it? Do you recognize it? Was this the same hos-
pital camp used by you in 1900?

9. Where was your hospital in 1900 - in tents, in the Cuartel or
in some other building? Is it shown in any of these photos?
10. What does the designation M.I.D. (on the photos) mean?

div1.p:
I do hope you can help me locate in these pictures: (a) your hospital
where you took care of the first cases of “pernicious malaria”, (b) the prison
where “cabine took sick. As I stated earlier, I believe you are the only one
who can help me in this matter, at least among those I know. Generals Kean and
Truby and Mr. Moran were never there as far as I know. If you can't help me,
is there some other person still alive who was there in 1900 who could help me?
Thank you very much for your help. Please remember me to Mrs. Cooke.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
